TEXT: CARDINAL . NORP The applicant , Mr NORP , is a GPE national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . He was represented before the ORG by PERSON , GPE , assisted by Mr PERSON , counsel .
CARDINAL . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , Mr PERSON of ORG
CARDINAL . The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

CARDINAL . During GPE recent civil war , the main fighting occurred between Government forces and ORG ( the ORG or “ NORP Tigers ” ) . In DATE , a paramilitary group broke away from the ORG ; this became known as the “ GPE group ” from the name of its leader PERSON ( alias “ Colonel PERSON ) . The political wing of this group was called ORG ( TamilEela Makkal PERSON : TVMP ) . DATE and DATE the GPE group fought with the Sri NORP armed forces against the NORP in GPE of GPE . In DATE GPE was expelled from the ORG after a dispute between him and his former deputy , PERSON ( also known as ORG ) . PERSON was later detained in GPE for immigration offences ; during this time the ORG was registered as a political party and , after elections in DATE , ORG became chief minister of GPE ( see ORG reports on GPE of DATE at annex C , p. CARDINAL and DATE at annex B , p. CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . The applicant arrived in GPE on DATE . He initially claimed to be visiting his brother but , when pressed , did not know his brother ’s address or phone number . When questioned further , he claimed asylum . He claimed to have formed a political party called ORG and to have stood as an independent candidate in the DATE provincial elections in GPE , LOC , in eastern GPE . In DATE , he had announced that he would publish a book giving details of human rights abuses of NORP in the district . He claimed that , on DATE , he was beaten up by CARDINAL unidentified men who warned him not to publish the book . He was later given a similar warning by telephone by the NORP . On DATE , at a branch meeting of the party , the applicant was attacked by an armed group who warned him to withdraw from the election or he would be killed . He attempted to report this incident to the police . On DATE , another group of armed men visited the party ’s office and made similar threats . The applicant believed these men belonged to the ORG group . A further attack took place on DATE when CARDINAL candidates from the applicant ’s party were attacked whilst putting up posters . DATE the applicant travelled to GPE and , the following day , he attended an anti - TMVP demonstration at which he was interviewed by ORG . He telephoned his home town and was told that , as a result of the interview , the Government and the ORG group were looking for him . He was warned not to return home . He nonetheless did so on DATE , and continued his political activities until DATE , DATE . His home was visited by armed men . Although he was not there at the time , his parents were given another warning . The applicant travelled to ORG ( also in LOC ) and then GPE . He fled to GPE using his GPE passport .

CARDINAL . His asylum claim was refused by the Secretary of ORG on DATE . It was found not to be credible that , in his asylum interview , the applicant had failed to remember the full name of the man with whom he had founded ORG or the name of CARDINAL other party candidates . He had failed to show whether the armed groups who had threatened him were affiliated to a political party and it was speculative to consider that they were Government forces . There were inconsistencies between the applicant ’s account and the transcript of the interview with the ORG . For instance , he had claimed to have spoken about removing arms from the ORG group and made comments about fair elections , neither of which were in the transcript . This indicated he had fabricated his account that he was of interest to the ORG group and the Government . He had also failed to mention in the transcript who had assaulted the party ’s candidates and thus there was no evidence that he had accused the ORG group or the Government of being responsible for the attacks . He had also referred to himself in the broadcast as “ a candidate of ORG of CARDINAL ” yet stated in his asylum interview that he belonged to ORG . It was also incredible that he would have returned home after the broadcast and , despite his fear of the Government , he had left GPE on his own passport without any difficulties . He had , by his own admission , never been harmed by the ORG or the ORG group and had no further problems with the NORP despite having published his book . Finally , the Secretary of ORG considered that the documents produced by the applicant in support of his claim , including an election card and poster , and a recording and transcript of the ORG interview , did not assist him in any material way . The recording had not been independently corroborated and the transcript was incomplete .

CARDINAL . The applicant appealed against the Secretary of ORG ’s refusal . His appeal was dismissed by the then ORG on DATE . It was accepted he had published the book as he had claimed and that this would have brought him to the attention of the ORG and the ORG . It was accepted that elections took place in eastern GPE on DATE and they had been marred by violence by paramilitary groups , including the ORG . It was surprising that the applicant had been unable to recall basic information as to his fellow candidates but it was accepted that the applicant had stood in those elections and the claims of harassment and attacks of the applicant and his party were consistent with the background evidence . The applicant ’s assumption that the armed men were part of the ORG group was entirely reasonable in the circumstances and it was credible that the ORG would have shown an interest in a rival party . The ORG was also satisfied that the applicant had given an interview at an anti - TMVP demonstration in GPE but it was not clear what he had said . It was further accepted that the applicant had been forced to flee as a result of the threats which had been made and the interview he had given . He would therefore be at risk in his home area . However , having considered this ORG ’s judgment in ORG . v. GPE , no . CARDINAL , DATE , ORG concluded that the applicant would be safe in GPE where the ORG were not active . There was insufficient evidence that he would be wanted by the Sri Lankan authorities rather than the ORG ; there was little evidence of harassment of opposition groups by the ORG as shown by the fact that the demonstration at which the interview had been given had passed off relatively peacefully . The applicant was not on a wanted list nor was there any outstanding arrest warrant . He would be questioned at GPE airport on return but not detained or ill - treated .

CARDINAL . An application for reconsideration of the determination was refused by a senior immigration judge on DATE , who found that , on the evidence before it , the ORG had been entitled to find as it did .

CARDINAL . The applicant ’s brother arrived in GPE on DATE with a student visa which was valid until DATE . He claimed asylum in GPE in DATE on the basis that he was suspected of assisting the ORG by providing a vehicle to transport weapons . He stated that he had previously earned a living in GPE by hiring CARDINAL vehicles but had decided to study in GPE and had handed his vehicles and business interests to a family friend . He had no problems prior to leaving GPE but , in DATE , his parents had telephoned to say that the police had come looking for him . The police had shown his parents an arrest warrant and told them that the family friend had been arrested while carrying weapons . The Secretary of ORG refused the asylum claim inter alia because the brother had initially said that the family friend had been arrested because he had been carrying election propaganda but later said that it was because he had been carrying weapons .

CARDINAL . The brother appealed to the First - tier ORG ) ( formerly ORG ) and produced a series of documents in support of his claim , including a letter from a GPE lawyer to the applicant ’s father and a copy of the arrest warrant with an LANGUAGE translation . Although the Secretary of ORG did not accept the authenticity of the documents ( arguing that forgeries were easily obtainable in GPE and that it was difficult to obtain a copy of one ’s own arrest warrant ) , attempts to verify their authenticity had not been successful .

CARDINAL . On DATE , the ORG allowed the brother ’s appeal . Although it had not been explained how the arrest warrant came into the possession of the family , the Secretary of ORG had not undertaken checks , had not appeared before the ORG and had not stated that the documents were forgeries . The arrest warrant was corroborated by the rest of the documents submitted by the brother , it was accepted it had been issued and further accepted that the police had visited the family home . Given the significance of an arrest warrant as a risk factor , the ORG concluded that there would be a real risk of ill - treatment on return .

CARDINAL . NORP The applicant made further representations to the Secretary of ORG on DATE and submitted further objective information in support of his asylum claim , which showed that opponents of the ORG were at risk and that a number of NORP had been murdered . CARDINAL . NORP The Secretary of ORG rejected the representations in a letter dated DATE . CARDINAL . Those documents have been provided to the ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE , the Secretary of ORG wrote to the applicant stating that the grounds which he relied on in the second judicial review application could reasonably have been raised in the previous judicial review application and she was not prepared to defer his removal unless a ORG injunction was obtained .

CARDINAL . ORG determination in LP ( NORP area DATE Colombo – risk ? ) GPE [ DATE ] UKAIT DATE was considered by ORG in ORG . , cited above , § § CARDINAL–CARDINAL . The headnote to the determination provided :

“ ( CARDINAL ) NORP are not per se at risk of serious harm from the Sri NORP authorities in GPE . A number of factors may increase the risk , including but not limited to : a previous record as a suspected or actual ORG member ; a previous criminal record and/or outstanding arrest warrant ; bail jumping and/or escaping from custody ; having signed a confession or similar document ; having been asked by the security forces to become an informer ; the presence of scarring ; return from GPE or other centre of NORP fundraising ; illegal departure from GPE ; lack of an ORG card or other documentation ; having made an asylum claim abroad ; having relatives in the ORG . In every case , those factors and the weight to be ascribed to them , individually and cumulatively , must be considered in the light of the facts of each case but they are not intended to be a check list .
( CARDINAL ) NORP If a person is actively wanted by the police and/or named on a Watched or Wanted list held at FAC , they may be at risk of detention at the airport .
( CARDINAL ) Otherwise , the majority of returning failed asylum seekers are processed relatively quickly and with no difficulty beyond some possible harassment .

( CARDINAL ) NORP in GPE are at increased risk of being stopped at checkpoints , in a cordon and search operation , or of being the subject of a raid on a ORG where they are staying . In general , the risk again is no more than harassment and should not cause any lasting difficulty , but NORP who have recently returned to GPE and have not yet renewed their GPE identity documents will be subject to more investigation and the factors listed above may then come into play .
( CARDINAL ) Returning NORP should be able to establish the fact of their recent return during the short period necessary for new identity documents to be procured .

( CARDINAL ) A person who can not establish that he is at real risk of persecution in his home area is not a refugee ; but his appeal may succeed under LAW ORG , or he may be entitled to humanitarian protection if he can establish he would be at risk in the part of the country to which he will be returned ... ”

CARDINAL . LP was reconsidered by the ORG in the light of ORG . in ORG ( NORP – LP updated ) GPE [ DATE ] UKAIT DATE . The ORG ’s conclusions were summarised in the headnote to the determination which , where relevant provides :
“ a ) The risk categories identified in ORG ( ORG area – NORP - Colombo – risk ? ) GPE [ DATE ] UKAIT DATE and approved by ORG ) in ORG v GPE , ORG . CARDINAL , remain valid .

b ) Events since the military defeat of the NORP in DATE have not aggravated the likely approach of the Sri NORP authorities to returned failed asylum seekers who are NORP ; if anything the level of interest in them has decreased . The principal focus of the authorities continues to be , not NORP from the north ( or east ) as such , but persons considered to be either NORP members , fighters or operatives or persons who have played an active role in the international procurement network responsible for financing the ORG and ensuring it was supplied with arms .

c ) The records the GPE authorities keep on persons with some history of arrest and detention have become increasingly sophisticated ; their greater accuracy is likely to reduce substantially the risk that a person of no real interest to the authorities would be arrested or detained . ”

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) and CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the Immigration Act DATE provide for the making of Immigration Rules by the Secretary of ORG . Paragraph CARDINAL of ORG provides as follows :

“ When a human rights or asylum claim has been refused or withdrawn or treated as withdrawn under paragraph CARDINAL of these Rules and any appeal relating to that claim is no longer pending , the decision maker will consider any further submissions and , if rejected , will then determine whether they amount to a fresh claim . The submissions will amount to a fresh claim if they are significantly different from the material that has previously been considered . The submissions will only be significantly different if the content :
( i ) had not already been considered ; and
( ii ) taken together with the previously considered material , created a realistic prospect of success , notwithstanding its rejection . ”

CARDINAL . As regards the scrutiny of fresh asylum claims and the power of the courts to review such scrutiny , ORG in PERSON ( ORG ) v. Secretary of ORG for ORG [ DATE ] EWCA Civ CARDINAL ( paragraphs CARDINAL ) has held :

“ Accordingly , a court when reviewing a decision of the Secretary of ORG as to whether a fresh claim exists must address the following matters . First , has the Secretary of ORG asked himself the correct question ? The question is not whether the Secretary of ORG himself thinks that the new claim is a good one or should succeed , but whether there is a realistic prospect of an adjudicator , applying the rule of anxious scrutiny , thinking that the applicant will be exposed to a real risk of persecution on return ... The Secretary of ORG of course can , and no doubt logically should , treat his own view of the merits as a starting - point for that enquiry ; but it is only a starting point in the consideration of a question that is distinctly different from the exercise of the Secretary of ORG making up his own mind . Second , in addressing that question , both in respect of the evaluation of the facts and in respect of the legal conclusions to be drawn from those facts , has the Secretary of ORG satisfied the requirement of anxious scrutiny ? If the court can not be satisfied that the answer to both of those questions is in the affirmative it will have to grant an application for review of the Secretary of ORG ’s decision . ”

Thus , an applicant making fresh representations must establish that they have a realistic prospect of success to establish a “ fresh claim ” which , even if then refused by the Secretary of ORG , will nonetheless generate a fresh right of appeal to be considered on the merits .
CARDINAL . GPE Information Service report on GPE of DATE includes ( at paragraph CARDINAL ) the following excerpt from a letter from ORG in GPE dated DATE :

“ Formally it is difficult for the accused to be able to obtain a copy of his / her own arrest warrant . When an arrest warrant is issued , a copy is kept on the legal file and the original is handed to the police . An accused can not apply for copies of the arrest warrant to the relevant court . However , in practice forged documents are easily obtainable throughout GPE . Additionally given ongoing and well documented concerns over corruption in the police it would probably not prove difficult to obtain a copy of an arrest warrant , although it would probably require prior contacts within the police service . ”
